skill.name: Using Superpowers
skill.description: Use when starting any conversation - establishes how to find and use skills, requiring Skill tool invocation before ANY response including clarifying questions
skill.summary: Establishes mandatory skill invocation workflow for AI assistants before taking any action
skill.author: obra

security_audit.summary: All four static findings are false positives. The static scanner misinterpreted markdown code formatting (backticks and triple backticks) as shell/Ruby command execution, and innocent YAML field text as cryptographic content. This is a documentation-only meta-skill containing skill invocation policies with no code execution, network access, or cryptographic operations.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at SKILL.md:16
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 16 uses markdown inline code formatting (single backticks) around 'Skill' tool name. This is documentation syntax, not shell command execution. No actual code or commands are present.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at SKILL.md:26
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 26 starts a Graphviz DOT diagram code block with triple backticks. This is markdown code block syntax for diagrams, not command execution. The content is a workflow diagram definition.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at SKILL.md:3
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 3 is a YAML description field containing text about skill invocation. It contains no cryptographic algorithms, hashes, encryption routines, or related code. This appears to be a scanner content pattern mismatch.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at SKILL.md:72
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 72 discusses skill priority ordering between process and implementation skills. No cryptographic content exists. This is a false positive from the static scanner's pattern matching.

content.value_statement: AI assistants often skip proper skill invocation when starting tasks. This skill establishes mandatory skill checks before any response or action, ensuring consistent workflow discipline across all interactions.
actual_capabilities: Enforces skill tool invocation before any response or action
Provides decision tree for when to use skills
Lists common rationalization patterns to avoid
Establishes skill priority ordering (process before implementation)
Differentiates rigid vs flexible skill types
Ensures clarifying questions come after skill checks
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Does not provide domain-specific technical guidance
Cannot replace human judgment on task approach
Only works when AI remembers to invoke it

use_cases.title: Standardize AI Behavior
use_cases.description: Ensure AI assistants follow consistent skill invocation patterns across all interactions and users.

use_cases.title: Enforce Process Discipline
use_cases.description: Prevent AI from skipping important workflow steps like brainstorming or debugging skills.

use_cases.title: Maintain Output Quality
use_cases.description: Reduce errors and oversights by requiring proper skill usage before task execution.

prompt_templates.title: Start Any Task
prompt_templates.prompt: Before responding, check if any skill applies. If there is even a 1% chance, invoke the skill.

prompt_templates.title: Clarification Questions
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if a skill tells you how to gather information before asking clarifying questions.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Actions
prompt_templates.prompt: Even for simple tasks, invoke relevant skills first. Do not skip the skill check step.

prompt_templates.title: Complex Projects
prompt_templates.prompt: Use process skills (brainstorming, debugging) before implementation skills. Follow the skill priority order.

output: Announcing: Using debugging skill to identify root cause
Creating todo items per debugging checklist
Following debugging process before attempting fixes
Creating todo items for ideation phase
Invoking skill even for simple questions

best_practices: Always announce which skill you are using and why before starting
Create TodoWrite items for each checklist item in the skill
Read the current version of a skill even if you remember it
anti_patterns: Skipping skill check because the task seems simple
Using a remembered skill instead of reading the current version
Rationalizing that a skill is overkill for the situation

faq.question: When should I invoke this skill?
faq.answer: At the start of every conversation or task before responding or taking any action.

faq.question: What if no skill seems to apply?
faq.answer: If you are confident no skill applies, you may respond directly. But be honest about the 1% rule.

faq.question: How do I prioritize multiple skills?
faq.answer: Use process skills (brainstorming, debugging) before implementation skills. Process determines approach.

faq.question: What about flexible skills?
faq.answer: Flexible skills (patterns) allow adaptation. Rigid skills (TDD, debugging) must be followed exactly.

faq.question: Can I skip skills for quick tasks?
faq.answer: No. Even simple tasks become complex. The skill check is mandatory regardless of task size.

faq.question: Do I need to read the skill every time?
faq.answer: Yes. Skills evolve. Always read the current version rather than relying on memory.
